fields.label_text:
British Galleries DAGUERREOTYPES
Daguerreotypes are the earliest widely known photographs: their startling clarity is still impressive. The image is made on a brightly polished sheet of silvered copper. This process was initially used almost entirely for commercial portraiture. The photographs here by early amateurs, Horatio Ross and William Edward Kilburn, show a fishing scene and a portrait, prototypes of the ever-popular 'family snapshot'.

Object Type
Daguerreotypes (an early type of photograph on a silvered copper plate) were usually protected by glass and sometimes kept in leather or thick plastic cases because the highly polished surface is easily scratched. The image is a unique positive made directly onto the plate without a negative, as in other forms of photography. Many daguerreotype photographers replaced miniature painters as makers of portraits as the process was quicker and less expensive.

Ownership & Use
Daguerreotypes were not made primarily for public display in exhibitions. Such small and intimate photographs were generally produced as private keepsakes and often remained within the family.

People
Kilburn opened a Daguerreotype studio in London in 1846. He advertised his portraits in the press stating that 'The likeness taken by the photographic process serves merely as a sketch for the miniature, which is painted by M. Mansion, whose productions on Ivory are so celebrated in Paris. They have when finished all the delicacy of an elaborate miniature, with the infallible accuracy of expression only obtainable by the photographic process. Three hand-coloured Daguerreotypes by Kilburn were shown at the Great Exhibition in 1851.

Daguerreotypes are unique, positive images made on highly polished copper plates coated with light sensitive silver. The neutral grey tones were criticised for making the sitters appear corpse-like. For a more life-like effect, daguerreotypes were sometimes painted over by hand. Kilburn opened his portrait studio on London's Regent Street in 1846, and was awarded a prize medal for his daguerreotype photographs at the 1851 Great Exhibition.

fields.descriptive_line: Portrait of Martha Emma Roper, hand-tinted daguerreotype in gilt mount and maker's case embossed with the studio name, by William Edward Kilburn.  British, c.1851.
fields.physical_description: The portrait shows a young woman in three quarter-length, with ringlets in her hair and a tartan dress with a pink bow around her neck. She is seated on an ornate dark wooden chair and she holds a partially open book.  It is a hand-tinted gilt Daguerreotype in a plush-lined papier-maché case, embossed with the studio's name and the Royal arms.

fields.bibliography: Coe, Brian & Haworth-Booth, Mark. A Guide to Early Photographic Printing Processes. London: The Victoria and Albert Museum in association with Hurtwood Press, 1983. The full entry of the text is as follows: William Edward Kilburn British Active 1846-1862 Portrait of Martha Emma Roper (1818-65) About 1851 Hand-tinted and gilt Daguerreotype in plush-lined papier-maché case, embossed with the studio's name and the Royal arms Image size 90 X 65 mm (reproduced same size) Mus. no. 1-1939 Given by J.L Nevinson The neutral grey tones of the Daguerreotype put it at a disadvantage with the miniature painting. Blackwood's Magazine in 1842 commented 'The likenesses produced...are so absolutely fearful, that we have but little hope of ever seeing anything tolerable from any machine. It must want colour...and its best likeness can be only that of a rigid bust, or a corpse'. For this reason, it was a common practice to add colour by hand. Often this would be no more than a touch of gilding on jewellery, or a faint flesh tint on hands or face. Sometimes, much more elaborate colouring was employed; colouring Daguerreotypes was a skilled business, since the fragile image could not be brushed over with heavy paint. In the main, one of two methods would be used. On involved the careful dusting-on of dry powder colour mixed with dry gum, which was fixed on the plate by breathing on it, a method patented by Richard Beard in 1842. Alternatively, colours mixed in alcohol could be painted on with care, drying rapidly to a transparent tint, a method introduced by Antoine Claudet. Colouring outfits cost from half a guinea for ten colours, including gold and silver, to two guineas for a box of 36 colours with all necessary implements. For the first five years of commercial Daguerreotyping in the London the medium was controlled as a near monopoly by Richard Beard. In 1846 he issued licenses to, among others, W.E. Kilburn, whose studio at 234 Regent Street offered the painted portrait Daguerreotype as a speciality; 'the likeness taken by the photographic process serves merely as a sketch for the miniature, which is painted by M. Mansion....They have, when finished, all the delicacy of an elaborate miniature with the infallible accuracy of expression obtained by the photographic process' (from an advertisement in The Athenaeum 10 April 1847). There was stiff competition among the leading studios for the best miniature painters; the combination of high quality Daguerreotypes and overpainting flourished until the closure of the studios of Kilburn and his great rival Claudet in 1862. Both studios were awarded medals at the Great Exhibition of 1851. That is the traditional date given to this portrait, which is supported by the style of the sitter's dress.
